If she but lay her rod upon your necks,
Transform you into apes, and swine, you sheep's face.
If thou shalt once but drink of her enchantments,
She'll make a lion of thee.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Alas sir,
I had rather look like an ass, as I am still.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Be not too boisterous, my son of thunder.
We are wellwishers to thy camp, and thee,
Here is a freshman, I would have acquainted
With the mystery of your iniquity.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: I do embrace thy league, and return the hand
Of friendship. To thy better understanding,
I will discover the situation of the place.
'Tis of itself an island, a mere swans nest:
Which had Ulysses seen, he would prefer
Before his Ithaca, and he whom fate
Shall bless to vanquish it; he may deserve
The name of a new conqueror. It has
The credit, to be styled the terra florida,
Of the best beauties in the town, my friend,
That repair hither upon the least summons,
Besides some that are constant to their trenches.
Venus in his house is predominant.
'Tis barren, I confess. Yet wholly given
To the deeds of fructication. But those
Are barred from coming to perfection,
With rheums, and diseases. You dormice,
What must I read a lecture to you gratis?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No sir, here's money for you.

sp.speaker: Pandar,
sp.l: You may enter,
And return safe, upon your good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Well, they may talk of Dunkirk, or of Callis,
Enriched with foreign booties, but if ever
A little garrison, or sconce, as this,
Were so filled up with spoils, let me be carted.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: And carry it so cunningly away,
Beyond the reach of justice, and of all
The jurisdiction in our own hand,
Like a free state.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did not I purchase it?
And am not I the lady of the manor?
And who shall dare to question me? I hope,
I shall be able to defend my fort,
From the invasion of the painted staff,
Or the tempestuous paper engine, safe,
As a mole in a trench, and work at high midnight.
When their wise heads are laid, we'll raise the spirits
Of our dead pleasures, use the benefit
Of youth, and dance our orgies by the moonlight.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: I hope they need not to condemn us, we drive
As open trade as they, and vent as ill
Commodities, as any: all that we utter,
Is in dark shops, or else by candlelight.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: We are become the envy of citizens.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: It is reported that we study physic.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: The reason is, because we know
The several constitutions of men's bodies.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: And some term us the leaguer ▪

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We defy
The force of any man, who's that knocks so?
Go bid the watch look out, and if their number
Be not too plural, then let them come in.
But if they chance to be those ruffian soldiers,
Let fall the portcullis. All they can do,
Is to discharge a volley of oaths at me.
I'll take no tickets, nor no future stipends.
'Tis not false titles, or denominations
Of offices can do it. I must have money.
Tell them so, draw the bridge. I'll make them know,
This is no widow's house, but Marcus Manitius,
Is lord of the island, who wast?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Pox on the marshal, and the constable.
There cannot be a mystery in a trade,
But they must peep into it. Merciless varlets,
That know how many fall by our occupation,
And yet would have their venery for nothing.
A chambermaid can't have a ruff to set,
But they must be poking in it;
Now they have brought us under contribution,
They vex us more than the Venetians do
The whole corporation of courtesans:
But we must give good words, show them a room.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: There's hot service within, I hear the musket's
Play from the rampires. I am valiant,
And will venture upon the very mouths of them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio, you have been a stranger.
You are grown rich of late.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Yes somewhat pursy for want of exercise.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, I was wont to put in for a gamester.
But now I am quite thrust out of all play.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We were wont to be your subjects to work on,
And since you scorn us, yet you cannot say,
But you have found good dealing at our hands.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.l: We have been always bent to your worships will
And forward to help you on at all times.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Truly sir you know,
I keep as good creatures at livery,
And as cheap too, as any poor sinner
Of my profession.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Hast thou ere a morsel,
That is not tainted, or fly blown?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Indeed I have
So much ado to keep my family sound,
You would wonder at it ▪ and such as are so,
They are taken up presently. But I have one,
I dare commend to you, for wind and limb.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Come, let me have her then.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Its strange there is no more attendance given,
To usher in a man of my quality.
Are you the governess of this cinqueport, lady?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: The fortress, sir, is mine, and none come here,
But pay me custom.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Hast thou ne'er a pilot,
Or man of war to conduct a man safe
Into thy harbour? there be rogues abroad.
Piratical varlets that would pillage me.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I thought at first, you would have barred my entrance.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: I do not use the fashions of those countries,
That keep a stranger out four weeks at sea,
To know if he be sound. I make no scruple,
But give free traffic to all nations.
If you have paid your due, you may put in,
There is the way, I'll follow presently.
I think our soldiers are all come, let's in
And set the watch.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Stay punk, make room for us,
That have advanced our banners to thy walls,
Passed all the pikes, the perdues, and the sentries.
'Tis a good omen, where's Bellona there,
And the daughters of Mars, those brave girls?
We are come to pay our homage to their smocks.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, if you are unruly, we shall tame you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Fear not, we are tributaries, punk.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Sir, do you speak with no more reverence
To me? it seems you know me not

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I shall
Endeavour to preserve thy dignity,
Art thou that brave Hippolyte, that governs
This troop of Scythians? Speak, Orsthya,
My Menalippe, my Antiope
We are sworn vassals to your petticoats.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did you attempt but the least injury,
There be in readiness, would vindicate
The wrongs, and credit of my house.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know
Thy power, punk, and do submit me, punk,
Tam marti, quam veneri. 'tis thy motto, punk.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: Would I could tell how to get out again.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How came you in? have you performed all duties?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I threw thy Cerberus a sleepy morsel,
And paid thy Charon for my waftage over.
And I have a golden sprig for my Proserpine.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay I do honour
Thee, and thy house, and all thy vermin in't.
And thou dost well to stand upon thy guard,
Spite of the statutes. 'tis a castle this,
A fort, a Metrapolitan bawdy house.
A Cynosarges, such as Hercules
Built in the honour of his pedigree,
For entertainment of the bastard issue
Of the bold Spartan.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: You have said enough, sir.
And for requital, I will show you in,
Where you shall read the titles, and the princes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: But here's a brother of mine is somewhat bashful:
I'd fain deliver him to thy discipline.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: What, is he bashful? that's a fault indeed.
Come hither, chops, you must not be so shamefaced?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Lo you there, sir, you shall come forth in print ▪
March on, my Calypso, come sir, follow your colours.
You shall have the leading of the first title,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Put it on your face.
Now they are hous●, I'll watch their coming forth,
And fright them in the form of a constable,
If that succeeds well, then I'll change the person,
To a justice of peace, and you shall act
My clerk Autolicus. They say an officer
Dares not appear about the gates: I'll try it.
For I have made one drunk, and got his staff.
Which I will use with more authority,
Than Mercury his all-commanding rod,
To charm their steps, that none shall pass this way;
Without examination. There stalks one,
I'll first know what he is; now they drop away,
As if they leapt out from the Trojan horse;
This is the autumn of the night: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Friend, or foe, come before the constable,

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: An't please you sir, I have
Been waiting on my niece, home to her lodging.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, is your niece a leagerer, a sutler,
Or laundress to this fort?

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: No, and it like you,
She lies without the camp.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You lie like a pimp.
You are an apple-squire, a rat, and a ferret.
I saw you bolt out from that cunny-berry.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Out of the wind of me what do you think,
You can put out the eyes of a gor-crow?
Fob me off so, the constable, that have
The parish stock of wit in my hands? I am glad,
That I have got you from your covert. You shall
Be learcht, you shall along with me sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: No farther than to prison, where you shall pay,
But forty shillings for noctivagation.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: I am undone then. There are forty old scores,
I owe in town, will follow after me.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: What are you? what's your name?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Ardelio,
A lords servant.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Alas, a venial sin, we use to learn it,
When we come first to be pages.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Stand by, there's one has got a clap too.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: The shirt of Hercules was not so hot.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: There's one sure has been hurt with a Gronieado.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Nobody . My senses fail me then, who is't?
What man are you?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: No man, you are deceived,
I can not find I am a man, that part
Is dead, wherein I once was an Achilles:

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I can not go, I have lost my nerves.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: You shall be carried to the jail then ▪

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Fitter
For an hospital. I am condemned already
To fluxes, and dyer drinks.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Who's that Heronimo's son's ghost in the garden?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: O Mr. constable, we have been so used,
As never two adventurous gentlemen
In the hands of their enemies.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let me take breath: I am at the last gasp.
We have escaped from the den of the Cyclops,
There was one ran a spit against my eyes.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Amongst the rest, there was a blink-eyed woman
Set a great dog upon me.

sp.speaker: Trm.
sp.l: They have spoilt us
Of our cloaks, our hats, our swords, and our money.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Your wits, and credit were both lost before.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: No, we had not our wits about us then.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good sir, let's think on some revenge, call up
The gentlemen prentices, and make a Shrove-tuesday.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: By no means, I must suppress all violence.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: My brother talked of building of a sconce,
And straight they seized our cloaks for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: There I lost my hat and sword in the rescue.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And whilst some strove to hold my hands,
The other dived in my pockets. I am sure,
There was a fellow with a tanned face, whose breath
Was grown sulphurous with oaths and tobacco,
Puffed terror in my face, I shall never be
Mine own man again.

sp.speaker: 1 who.
sp.p: 'Twere a good deed to have made them swim the moat.

sp.speaker: 2 who.
sp.p: Ay, to have stripped them, and sent them out naked.

sp.speaker: 1 who.
sp.l: Let's sally out, and fetch them in again.
Then call a court on them for false alarms.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Fly from their rage, sir; they are worse than harpies,
They'll tear us, as the Thracians did Orpheus,
Whose music, though it charmed the powers of hell,
Could not be heard amongst these. Mr. Ardelio
And Miscellanio, I joy to see you,
Though ill met here.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Signior Trimalchio,
Sir you must pardon me. I can not stoop.
I have the Grincum's in my back, I fear
Will spoil my courtship.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio,
Who would expected to have met you here?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay, who would not expect it? 'tis my haunt.
I love it, as a pigeon, loves a salt-pit.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: O me! my scholar too how came he hither?
I did not mean t'impart this mystery.
How could he find it out?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: His own Minerva,
And my helped, sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Marry, before a justice,
To answer for your riot.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: I can not dispense with it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Not before next sessions. Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Was ever such a treacherous plot intended,
Against our state, and dignity?

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: Had this
Passed with impunity, they might have sworn,
Vengeance had run the country.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: But I hope,
They have no cause to boast their victory,

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: Now by this air, as I am a true soldier,
Bred under, and devoted to your Banne,
But that your pity did prevent my rage,
They should have known no quarter, for this brow
Brooks no affronts.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We'll have a stone graven with characters.
To intimate your prowess.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: No, my dear Gorgon's,
I will not have my same wander without
The precincts of your castle: 'tis enough
It can be sheltered here, within these walls.
And to recount with your acknowledgements,
What this fort owes to my protection.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Captain, we must confess you are our guardian.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: Then let me sacrifice unto my humour.
All you this night, shall be at my disposing,
To drink and dra●, 'tis the fault of your fortune
That do profess this trade, t'have somebody,
To spend your purchase on, 'tis my decree,
What others riot, you should waste on me.

div.head: Actus 4. Scene 4.
div.stage: Agurtes like a justice of peace. Antelicus his clerk.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Then let me see
How I can act it: do I look like a justice?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: As fearful as an ass in a lion's skin, sir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Here I begin my state. Suppose me now
Come down the stairs, out of the dining room,
Into the hall, and thus I begin. Brisco.
Call Brisco my clerk.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Reach me my ensign of authority,
My staff I mean. Fie, fie, how dull you are,
And incomposed? Now set me in my chair,
That I may look like a cathedral justice,
That knew, what belongs to an assignanimus,
And dedimus potestatis. Nay, though we are
O● the peace, we can give Priscian a knock.
Let me alone now to determine causes,
As free from error as the Pope. Old Minos,
And Rhadmanth, are not so skiled ith' urn,
As I am in the statutes. I have them ad unguem
Now if they enter, at their peril be it.
How dost thou like my action?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let them come in.
sp.stage: Enter Snarle like a constable. Trimalchio, Capritio, M●scellanio, Ardelio.
sp.l: Now Mr. Constable,
I must commend your diligence. Come hither.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Sir I have borough four men before your worship,
I found last night, at midnight, in the streets,
Raising a tumult.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Brisco, be ready to take
Their examination. Good: you found four men,
At midnight. Whose men are they?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: So it seems by your liveries.
Write that down; first they say, they are their own men.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: Sir, by your favour, I am not my own man.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I thought they would not all be in one tale,
I knew I should find them tripping, and I
Once come to sift them. You are not your own man.
It argues you are drunk. Write his confession,
Ex os tuum te iudico: perge Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: I hold it fit, your worship should examine
What they did there so late,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: What did you there
So late?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: Good justice echo, we had business.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Record, they say they had business. They shall know.
That I am judge of record, and what I do
Record, shall stand, and they shall have no power
To plead not guilty in a scire facias,
By a recognisance. I have my terms.

sp.speaker: Ardel
sp.p: Good your worship, give us not such hard words.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: 'Tis almost as hard usage as the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Then you came from the leaguer?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: You may read
Some adventures in our habit, we have seen,
And tasted the experience of the wars.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: They have made me of another religion,
I must turn Jew, I think, and be circumcised.
I may be any thing, now I shall lose a limb.
I may go seek my pension with the soldiers.
But 'tis no matter, I'll turn valiant,
And fight with the stump.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You are a fighter then.
This doth appear to me, to be a riot.
What think you, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: I know not
What you mean, but I mean as your worship means.
I did perceive they had been quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why then 'twas an affray, a sudden affray,
Directly against the state of Northampton.
The decimo tertio of Harry the fourth clears the doubt.
How do you traverse this? what do you answer?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: We make a question, by your worship's favour,
Under correction, whether that which was
Done under foreign powers, in foreign lands,
Be punishable here or no.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: 'Tis a province by itself, a privileged place,
A strong corporation, and has factions
In court and city.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is inhabited
With furies, that do multiply like Hydra:
An army of diseases can't suppress them,
Besides their many fallings tother way.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I should be loath t'infringe their liberties,
I'll send you to betrayed, from whence you came then.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: O good your worship, hang us up at home first,
Let us endure the rack or the strappado,
We do submit us to your worship's censure.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Have you provided sureties for the peace then?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: More need to provide somethings for my belly.
I think they mean to keep me for a race.
I am fallen away quite, I was like a hogshead.
Now I amable to run thorough my hoops.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: What's he that halts before 〈◊〉 do you mock me?
'Tis ill halting before a cripple, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: This sore against my will, I can not help it.
Would I could run away with half my teeth.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Can't a man have the venerable gout,
Or the bone-ache, but you must imitate him?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Mock your fellow rogues.
I am none of those, that raised my fortunes with
Fiddling and tobacco. Make his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: An't please you sir, here's one has brought a letter.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: He says, from one mistress Millescent,
The contents will inform you.

stage.p:
Noble sir, I am sorry to interest my unstayed honour in the patronage of offenders, or to abuse the credit I have with you, in stopping the course of justice against them, whose youthful licentiousness, would pollute the pen of a lady to excuse it. On the other part, i hold it the betraying of a virgin's sweet disposition, to withdraw her favours, where she has once placed them, although there be some want of desert. I must confess 'tis an antipathy to my nature, to see any gentleman suffer, when I may prevent it. Howsoever I have found a disrespect from him, yet I forget it. For anger abides in the bosoms of women, as snow on the ground: where it is smooth and level, it falls quickly off, but remains where it is rough and uneven. That this may appear to be true, I would entreat you to dismiss those two gentlemen and their associates, mr. Trimalchio, and Capritio, whose riotous looseness has made them obnoxious to your censure, and my suspicion. Thus
not doubting the success of my letter, I rest in your favour as you may presume on mine, and your true friend,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: This lady, that has writ in your behalf,
Is one I honour.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: It ●●●●es, your fault is quickly blown abroad.
〈…〉 rather seal a noverint universi,
For a thousand pound stale commodities,
Then thee should know of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: As for you two,
You may pay your fees and depart, you have
Your manumission, or this lady's sake.
Master. Constable, you are discharged, and you may
Go along with them and receive their fees.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: Though I say nothing, yet I smell something:
A lady send a letter? She is, in love
With me, I'll pawn my life, and I ne'er knew it.
I'll get my back well, and go visit her.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Now I have got my teeth at liberty,
And they ere tie me to the rack again,
Let me be choked.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Well, I perceive you are
A favourite to this lady. What's your name?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Two ancient names in Camden, of what country?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: The Capritios of Norfolk.
I think we shall be kin anon. My mother
Was a Capritie, and of that house;
Are you allied unto this lady?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No sir.
But I have formerly been entertained
As a poor tutor to her grace's favour.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I find by that, you are a man of fashion.
And would you then?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay good sir, do not chide.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Yes, I must tell you, that you were to blame,
Having so fair a fortune before you, to wrong
A lady of her spirit; so rich, and fair,
Of unreproved chastity, and one
So high in birth, nay 'tis not possible
To speak her virtues, and present yourself
So lumpishly, nay perhaps fill her bed
Full of diseases.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good sir, say no more.
I am a●raycor, I have killed a man,
Committed sacrilege. Let her seek revenge
For these, or if less punishment will serve:
To have me beaten, I'll run naked to her.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I will not press a good nature so far:
You two shall stay and dine with me. I'll send
My coach for your mistress, it shall go hard:
But I will make you friends, before we part.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: Now let me bid you welcome from the wars,
Laden with conquest, and the golden fleece
Of honour, which like Jason, you have brought
T'enrich your country, now indebted to you.
Had it not been a pity such a talon
Of virtue should be lost or ill employed?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lady, you are a good physician,
It was your counsel wrought this miracle,
Beyond the power of Aesculapius:
For when my mind was stupefied, and lost
In the pursuit of pleasures: all my body
Torn, and dissected with close vanities,
You have collected me anew to life:
And now I come to you, with as chaste thoughts,
As they were first adulterous, and yield
A due submission for the wrong I did
Both to yourself, and sex.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: Sir. for my part,
You have your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You were born to quit me.

sp.speaker: Fude.
sp.l: But when you know the author of your freedom,
You'll thank her more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? not Faustina? she told me so indeed,
Her name was Faustina. Let me look upon her,
As on the picture of all goodness, engraven
By a celestial finger, shall wear out:
A marble character. I knew her not,
I am glad there is a scion of our stock.
Can bear such fruit as this, so ripe in virtue.
Where have you lived recluse? you were betrothed
To one Fidelio; but crossed by your father.
I have heard good reports of the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: I never knew you flatter any man
Unto his face before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Unto his face?
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am transported, ravished: give me leave
Good gods, to entertain with reverence,
So great a comfort. Let me first embrace you.
Great joys, like griefs, are silent. Lose me now,
And let me make you fast. Here join your hands,
Which no age shall untie. Let happiness
Distil from you, as the Arabian gums,
To bless your issue.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: Now I hope, sweet lady,
The time has put a period to your vow.

sp.speaker: Faust.
sp.l: 'Tis ended now, and you may take a comfort,
That I could tie myself to such a law.
For you may hope thereby, I shall observe you
With no less strict obedience.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And for her dowry, I will treble it,
Here sanrle is come to be a witness to it.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: My lord Philautus, if I may presume
To congratulate your honour's safe return,
I must confess, I do it with my heart,
And all your friends long to participate
Your happy presence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thanks both to them and thee.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Master Fidelio, no less to you.
I see you happy in your mistress favour:
And that's as much, as I can wish to you.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: You have been always privy to my counsel
Ask me no questions now, I shall resolve you
When we come in.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How fares our camp at home,
Trimalchio, and the rest?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: I have been busy,
In projecting for them, they must all be married.
I have seen the interlude of the leaguer:
And we have played the justice, and the constable:
I will not prepossess you with the sport,
But I will show you such a scene of laughter.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Your servant Ardelio.
'Tis the notorioust mixture of a villain,
That ever yet was bred under the dunghill
Of servitude. He has more whores at command,
Than you have horses. He has stables for them,
His private vaulting houses.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Discharge him the house.
Take his accounts and office, and dispose them.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ever your lordship's true and faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.p: When was my father, and the captain here?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: They are plotting abroad, I hope to see you shortly
Honestly married, and then turn virtuous.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: 'Tis the course of the world now, Margery.
But yet I fear, I have got such a trick,
When I was young, that I shall never leave it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What help then? the poor gentleman must suffer,
Good Trimalchio: 'tis his fate.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I am thinking,
What I shall do with him, when I am married.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What do other women do with their husbands?
Bring him up in obedience, make him besides
An implement to save your reputation.
Let him not press into your company
Without permission, you must pretend,
You are ashamed of him. Let him not eat,
Nor lie with you, unless he pay the hire
Of a new gown, or petticoat: live with him,
As if you were his neighbour, only near him,
In that you hate his friends: and when you please.
To show the power you carry over him,
Send him before on foot, and you come after
With your coach and four horses.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: 'Tis fitting so
Host now what piece of motion have we here
Would you speak with anybody ?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: My business,
Is to the lady Millescent.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: To you then I direct my apology.
It seems your eye with approbation,
Has glanced upon my person. I protest
I never was so dull in the construction
Of any lady's favour in my life:
I am ashamed of my error.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: In what, sir?
I can not call to mind that ere I saw you.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: You have been still too modest to conceal it.
That was not my fault: you did ill to strive
To hide the flames of love, they must have vent:
'Tis not the walls of flesh can hold them in.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: What riddles have we here? that I should love you?
I would not have you think so well of yourself.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Perhaps he has some petition to deliver,
Or would desire your letter to some lord.

sp.speaker: Misce.
sp.l: I know not how, sure I was stupified,
I have ere now guessed at a lady's mind,
Only by the warbling of her lutestring,
Kissing her hand, or wagging of her feather,
And suffer you to pine for my embraces,
And not conceive it?

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Pray be pacified.
This fellow will persuade me, I am in love.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Lady, you have taken notice of my worth
Let it not repent you. Be not stubborn
Towards your happiness. You have endured
Too much already for my sake, you shall see,
Pity can melt my heart. I take no delight,
To have a lady languish for my lioe.
I am not made of flint as you suspect me.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I would thou wert converted to a pillar,
For a memorial of this impudence.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: You shall know what 'tis to tempt me hereafter,
When I shall let you perish for your folly.
I came to remunerate the courtesy,
I received from your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: I must acknowledge myself bound to you

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Your letter to the justice, lady,
It freed me from the pounces of those varlets,
When I was under the gripe of the law.
I know, the only motive was your love.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, were you one of them
That drew Trimalchio to those idle courses?
I am ashamed of the benefit, leave me
That I may not see the cause of my sorrow:
But 'tis no matter, we shall leave you first.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: They shall find, I am no man to be slighted,
And that she has misplaced her affection.
When I have wracked the wrongs on my corrival,
Trimalchio, look to thyself, were he removed,
There might be hopes, my valour shall make known
There is a difference. I'll straight to the tavern:
And when I once am hot with good canary,
I pronounce him dead that affronts my fury.

sp.speaker: Ardelio.
sp.l: Turned out of service the next turn will be
Under the gallows, and have a ballad made of me,
The corruption of a cashiered servingman,
Is the generation of a thief. I scare,
My fate points me not out to so good fortune.
My bulk will not serve me to take a purse.
The best thing I am fit for, is a tapster,
Or else get a wench of mine own, and sell
Bottle ale and tobacco, that's my refuge
They termed me parasite, 'tis a mystery
Is like a familiar, that leaves a man
When he is near his execution.
I have no power to flatter myself now,
I might have gone a-wooing to some widow,
And had his countenance, but now the tenants
Look like their bacon, rustily, upon me.
What, Jeffery! thou art the comfort of my woes:
Welcome, good Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Very well, sir.
Locked in a cypress chest, for fear of moths.

sp.speaker: Aed.
sp.p: And all the other furniture good Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: They are kept safe, and well aried for your worship.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Thanks, good Jeffry. I were in a sweet case,
If I had not conveyed somethings away,
To maintain me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I may go set up bills now for my living,
Cry vinegar up and down the streets; or fish
At black friars stairs; or sit against
A wall, with a library of ballads before me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: You are not out of service.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Turned a grazing,
In the wide common of the world, Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Then are my hopes at best, I have no reason
To care for him any longer; a word with you.
What furniture do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Those that I sent,
The beds, and hangings.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: I hope you will not use me so.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Your own words.
I must make the best benefit of my place:
You know, 'tis not an age to be honest in.
'Tis the only highway unto poverty.
I know not how, I do not fancy you
Of late.

sp.speaker: Arde.
sp.l: I chose thee for thy knavish look.
And now thou hast requited me: of all
My evils, thou art the worst.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: No faith, sir.
You have a worse commodity at my house.
But you may save the charges of a writ.
I'll send her you without reprieve or bail.
I do you that favour.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: No, you may keep her still.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: My thinks you are much dejected with your fall,
I find an alteration in your face.
You look like an almanac of last years date.
Or like your livery cloak, of two years wearing.
Worse than the smoky wall of a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Villain, dost thou insult on me?

sp.speaker: Jeff
sp.l: No faith sir,
Alass, 'tis not within the reach of man,
To countermine your plots.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, slave, because
I'll rid my hands of thee, I'll give thee a share.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: You must have none, without lawful proceeding.
And that I know, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: But I dare.
Have you been partners all this while in mischief,
And now fall out, who shall be the most knave?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: I mean to search your house
For ammunition, no otherwise,
Which I suspect you send unto the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Sir I have nothing there, but one cracked piece
Belongs to this gentleman, can do no service.
She is spoilt in the bore.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: We'll have her new cast.
Come, bring them away.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay good sir, you know,
That I was lately quit before a justice.
And if I fall in a relapse.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: All's one
To me, but you must satisfy the law.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Well then, I know the worst of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Master Trimalchio, 'tis an age since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I was ne'er out of town.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Not out of town?
We sought you about all the ordinaries,
Taverns and bawdy-houses, we could imagine
You ever haunted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You might have found us then.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Nay more, we enquired at the playhouses.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: 'Twas once in my mind, to have had you cried.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, shall I tell you, captain?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: This gentleman and I
Have passed through purgatory, since I saw you.
If I should tell you all the passages
At the leaguer.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Thither we came to meet you,
And you were gone.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis such a story
Would fill a chronicle.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: We met with a party of the enemies,
Took all we had from us, and then it cost us
Forty shillings in fees at the justices.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: The old boy and I
Grew to be kin at last.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He made me sure
To my mistress, before we parted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Honest Ardelio,
And Misellanio, we were all together
In rebellion, and quit by a letter,
That came from my mistress.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Is't possible?
And Miscellanio turn traitor?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would have your mistress from you, thinks the letter
Was sent for his sake.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: That I am sure he does not.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Threatens, and swears that he will fight for her.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: If he be weary of his life, he may.
Why what can he pretend to her?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I know not,
What has passed between them, but I am sure,
He has been practising at the fencing school,
To get a trick to kill you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He kill me!
I'll kill him first. I fight by geometry.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes sir, here I hold
My rapier, mark me, in a diameter
To my body; that's the centre, conceive me.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Your body is the centre, very good.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And my hilt, part of the circumference.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Which hilt is bigger than my body.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes at such a distance.
And he shall never hit me, whilst he lives.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Where did you learn this? At the leager?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No.
No by this light: it is my own invention.
I learned it in my travels.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Very strange:
You are a scholar.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: No: I would not be
Suspected of such a crime for a million.
But 'tis no sin to know geometry;
And by that, I can tell we shall ne'er fight.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'll show you in geometry,
Two parallels can never meet: now we two
Being parallels, for so we are, that is
Equal in wit and valour, can never meet.
And if we never meet, we shall ne'er fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: To prove your axiom false, see where he comes ▪

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Hang thee blustering son
Of Aeolus, defy me! I'll tie up thy breath
In bags, and sell it for a penny an ounce.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: Sure, this is the second part of the leaguer.
'Twere best for me, to hide me in my cabin.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: Unless you'll have her ta'en away by force.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: I see, this cannot be ended without blood.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I am afraid he comes with the black art.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: How you afraid? do not say so for shame.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He has lain with an old witch at Sweden.
And is grown stick free.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Fie that you shall say so.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I'll be resolved of that before I fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Why, do you think that witches have such power?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I marry do I, I have known one of them,
Do more than that, when her husband has followed
Strange women, she has turned him into a Bezer,
And made him bite out his own stones.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'll tell you another as strange as that, of one
When a vintner has sent her but ill wine,
She has converted him into a frog.
And then conjured him into one of his butts,
Where he has lived twelve months upon the lees,
And when his old guests chance to come to see him,
He has croaked to them, out at the bunghole.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: There was a lawyer
That spoke against one of them at the bar.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Turned him into a ram,
And still that ram retains his profession,
Has many clients, and pleads causes as well
As some lawyers in Westminster.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Do you think,
That he has had recourse to any such?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know not, but 'tis good to be mistrustful.
He may have advantage in the encounter.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: There she comes, win her, and wear her.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Hold your hands.
I'll have no blood a prologue to my wedding.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then have at you. Hold me not, I say
I am as fierce as he.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Be pacified.
I thought you had been both bound to the peace.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Lady, it seems, that these two gentlemen
Do stand in competition for your love.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: Mr. Trimalchio, I confess, has been
A former suitor, but with his ill carriage,
He has thus long prevented his good fortune.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Then let me make a motion.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Will they both stand to it?

sp.speaker: Autol.
sp.p: Then let the lady dispose of herself.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: She is mine already. I am sure to her,
Before a justice.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: I will have no woman,
Against her will.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: No sir, nor you shall not,
Since you are so peremptory, on your words then
That he shall sing a palinodium,
And recant his ill courses, I assume
My love Trimalehio.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.p: Do we take, or are we taken?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Who's that, Capritio? where have you been?
Come your ways forth, and lay hands on the spoil.
Go lead away that lady by the hand.
Now you may take occasion by the foretop,
Advance your own predominant the better,
And march away,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come, let us to the church.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.p: And what must I do now? be laughed at?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would you
Hazard yourself, for one that cares not for you?
You may be glad you 'scaped. Recall yourself.
Were not you formerly engaged?

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Faith we have toyed
In jest sometime.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let it be now in earnest.
Make her amends. I know she loves you.

sp.speaker: Miscel.
sp.l: Well.
I will have her, and stand up for my portion,
With the rest of my tribe.

div.head: Scaena ultima.

sp.speaker: Snarl
sp.l: Stay here a little, they are gone to church,
And will return in couples. First, Trimalchio,
That giant in conceit, thinks he is matched
To some great heir, but shall embrace a cloud
In stead of Juno. Then her waiting woman,
Her Iris, reflects upon Capritio,
And for my piece of fragmentary courtship,
My miscellany gentleman, 'tis his lot
To be cast upon Quartilla with agurtes
In his old justiceship. All these march together,
Like the seven deadly sins, and behind them,
Comes Autolicus, the clerk of the company.

div.stage: Trimalchio, Millescent. Miscellanio, Quartilla, Capritio, Margery, Antolicus like a clerk,

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Look you sir, here they come.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Make room, methinks
You should not stop the course of justice so.
My lord Philantus, you are welcome from
The wars, and I from the church. I wonder
Who makes the better return, you have got
Honour, and so have I. But where's your wealth?
I can embrace five thousand pounds, a year.
That's nothing with you, I have no more wit,
Than to be pied by pimps, and marry whores,
Yet I mean shortly to rank with your honour.
Here is my warrant, I have promised her,
To make her a countess, but that's nothing with you,
Nay, more than this I can go on, and leave
Some advancement: behind me. Ecce signum,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I am glad of your happiness,
And much joy to my brother Capritio,
And his fair spouse.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: She is according to
My heart's desire, sir.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Well, a word with you,
Master Trimalchio, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: You were as good know it at first, as at last.
You are not the first, that have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: In what? my wife? I married her for a maid.
And whether she be one, or no, I care not.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Nay, should I hear a man that should abuse her
In that, I would defend her with my sword.
But she and you must call this man your father.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I so she must, he gave her at the church.

sp.speaker: Snarl
sp.l: Nay, her own natural father, flesh and bone,
I hope she'll not deny it.

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: No indeed, sir.
I would not live to be so ungracious.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I must acknowledge thee my child, or I
Should do thy mother wrong.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I do not think so,
You'll not make me believe that I took her
For a lord's daughter, and a great heir. Where are
Agurtes and the captain to justify it?
Is he your father?

sp.speaker: Milles.
sp.l: He has ever bred me:
And I have always called him so. I hope
It is no shame: my parentage is honest.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Well, if he be, 'tis no disparagement,
To marry a justice's daughter.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Come, you have
Been carried hood winked through this business.
Nor is the day yet clear before you. Mark me;
I'll open but one leaf in all the book,
And you shall see the whole discovery.
Come sir, unease.

div.stage: Agurtes and Antolicus pull off there disguises.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Who have we here? Agurtes
And the captain? Was't you that played the justice?
And you his clerk?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Then you are a knot of knaves for your labour.
Now I perceive that I am plainly gulled.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.p: I am glad there's no man cheated but himself.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Your arrow is one of the same quiver too.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I'll none of her by this light.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, you may choose.
And yet I do not well see, how you can choose.
She is your wife, and you have married her,
And must allow her means to maintain her.
You may declare yourself unto the world.
And be laughed at: but keep your own counsel,
And who needs know of it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Believe me sir,
The gentlewoman is not to be despised,
Her wit and virtues are dowry sufficient.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay, if you say so, then must I needs love her:
But by this hand, I thought you would have jeered me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold on your course, march on as you came in,
And rest content, since fate has thought it fit,
To make your fortunes equal with your wit.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
